newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Rights groups warn Nigeria could be another Zaire.
newsitem.headline: Rights groups warn Nigeria could be another Zaire.

text.p: A human rights group in Nigeria on Wednesday launched a campaign against alleged rights violations, saying the West African nation could slide into ethnic conflict like Zaire.
Tribal warfare betwen Hutus and Tutsis in east Africa has left the eastern flank of sprawling Zaire in chaos, stranding hundreds of thousands of refugees.

"Rights abuses by the military government could turn Nigeria into another Zaire if local and international communities don't stem the tide," Clement Nwankwo, head of the Constitutional Rights Project (CRP), told a news conference in Lagos.
"The crisis in Zaire started in the same manner as the way the Nigerian military has been unlawfully detaining, intimidating and eliminating imagined enemies," he added.
Earlier, London-based group Amnesty International released a report on Africa's most populous country that accused the state of being openly contemptuous of human rights.
It reported little improvement in Nigeria since the government drew worldwide condemnation last November 10 for hanging author Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight minority rights activists of the Ogoni tribe.
"As the first anniversary of their execution draws near, little has changed," Amnesty International said. "The present military government in Nigeria has a record of open contempt for human rights."
"The government continues to violate the human rights of its critics, including opposition politicians, journalists, human rights activists and members of the Ogoni ethnic group."

Nwankwo said Nigerian rights groups planned a three-day ceremony starting on Saturday to mark the anniversary of the executions of the nine men. They had been convicted of the murder of four Ogoni chiefs in a trial critics termed flawed.
Prayers and peaceful processions will be held simultaneously in southeastern Port-Harcourt, where the nine were executed, and at the Lagos university campus, he said.
Nigeria's special duties minister Wada Nas on Monday accused Amnesty International of planning to foment trouble by staging demonstrations on the anniversary.
The Lagos chapter of Amnesty International in a statement on Wednesday denied the accusation.

Nigeria, under military rule for 25 years since its independence in 1960, plunged into turmoil in 1993 when a presidential vote presumed to have been won by millionaire businessman Moshood Abiola was annulled by the army.
Abiola has been detained since 1994 when he proclaimed himself president in defiance of military ruler General Sani Abacha, who seized power in the mayhem that followed the annulment.
Several opposition men are also in detention or have fled abroad since strikes and riots were organised in 1994 to force Abacha to cede power to Abiola.

About half a dozen detainees have been released since the United Nations sent a fact-finding mission to Nigeria. The U.N. report endorsed Abacha's transition to civil rule programme but called for detainees to be freed and draconian laws reformed.
Abacha is implementing a programme of phased elections that he says would usher in an elected civilian government by October 1998.
